G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 exclusive of interests and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue properly lies in this Court under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the acts and omissions complained of occurred in Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 260, \u00a7 2A.proposition: Plaintiff duly complied with applicable notice requirements, and this suit is timely filed under G.L. c. 260, § 2A (three-year statute of limitations for tort actions).

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: The duty arises under common law and statutes including G.L. c. 90, § 14, which specifically prohibits a person from opening the door of a motor vehicle unless it can be done safely and without interfering with traffic.

Restatement (Second) of Torts \u00a7 282.proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute negligence as defined under Massachusetts law, including Restatement (Second) of Torts § 282, and by cases such as Glenn v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 442 (1911) (defining actionable negligence as failure to exercise care of an ordinarily prudent person).

Glenn v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.raw_text: Glenn v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 442 (1911)
Glenn v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s actions constitute negligence as defined under Massachusetts law, including Restatement (Second) of Torts § 282, and by cases such as Glenn v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Mass. 442 (1911) (defining actionable negligence as failure to exercise care of an ordinarily prudent person).
Glenn v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion applies the concept of negligence and due care but does not clearly define ‘actionable negligence’ in the abstract or articulate a standard such as ‘failure to exercise the care of an ordinarily prudent person.’ The quoted portion focuses on whether the plaintiff was in the exercise of due care and whether the evidence warranted a finding of negligence by the defendant (who failed to see the plaintiff), not on a general definitional statement of negligence. Thus it is related to negligence doctrine but is a weak or indirect source for the specific definitional proposition cited.
Glenn v. Boston Elevated Ry. Co., 208 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “If the jury found these to be the facts they were at least warranted in finding that the plaintiff was in the exercise of due care. … The only persons in the car were the defendant’s wife and his chauffeur, neither of whom saw the plaintiff, and both of whom testified that they never knew of the accident to the plaintiff until told of it after it had occurred. This again at least warranted a finding of negligence.”

Delano v. Garrettson, 351 Mass. 779 (196.proposition: Massachusetts recognizes a duty owed by motorists to exercise due care toward bicyclists (Delano v. Garrettson, 351 Mass. 779 (1967); Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co., 343 Mass. 414 (1961)).

Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co., 343 Mass..raw_text: Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co., 343 Mass. 414 (1961)
Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co., 343 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts recognizes a duty owed by motorists to exercise due care toward bicyclists (Delano v. Garrettson, 351 Mass. 779 (1967); Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co., 343 Mass. 414 (1961)).
Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co., 343 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns premises liability (duty of a landowner to an invitee) and does not involve motor vehicles, bicyclists, or any roadway duty of care. It establishes the duty of a property owner toward an invitee on building premises, not a duty of motorists toward bicyclists. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition about motorists’ duty of due care to bicyclists in Massachusetts.
Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co., 343 Mass..relevant_excerpt: "If the plaintiff was an invitee the defendant owed her the duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition for her use or at least to warn of dangers known to the defendant but not obvious to the ordinary person."

Gross v. Republic Taxi Serv., Inc., 2016.raw_text: Gross v. Republic Taxi Serv., Inc., 2016 Mass. App. Div. 105 (2016)
Gross v. Republic Taxi Serv., Inc., 2016.proposition: “Dooring” incidents are addressed in cases and codes affirming that failure to check before opening a vehicle door constitutes actionable negligence (Gross v. Republic Taxi Serv., Inc., 2016 Mass. App. Div. 105 (2016)).

Issacson v. Boston, 241 Mass. 477 (1922).proposition: Under Issacson v. Boston, 241 Mass. 477 (1922), and Hook v. Springfield Street Ry. Co., 215 Mass. 436 (1913), negligence may be found where a defendant fails to maintain proper lookout or performs an act foreseeably dangerous to others.
Issacson v. Boston, 241 Mass. 477 (1922).support_reasoning: Issacson v. Boston is an equity case about the enforceability and scope of a noncompete/confidentiality agreement in the laundry business. It does not involve negligence, duty of care, lookout obligations, or foreseeably dangerous acts, nor does it discuss standards for finding negligence. The proposition about negligence and failure to maintain a proper lookout is therefore not supported by this opinion, which is focused entirely on restraint-of-trade and confidential information issues.
Issacson v. Boston, 241 Mass. 477 (1922).relevant_excerpt: "It long has been settled that contracts restraining freedom of employment can be enforced only when they are reasonable and not wider than is necessary for the protection to which the employer is entitled and when not injurious to the public interest."

Hook v. Springfield Street Ry. Co., 215.raw_text: Hook v. Springfield Street Ry. Co., 215 Mass. 436 (1913)
Hook v. Springfield Street Ry. Co., 215.proposition: Under Issacson v. Boston, 241 Mass. 477 (1922), and Hook v. Springfield Street Ry. Co., 215 Mass. 436 (1913), negligence may be found where a defendant fails to maintain proper lookout or performs an act foreseeably dangerous to others.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Massachusetts adheres to the principles of comparative negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85, but Plaintiff was at all times using due care and any alleged contributory negligence was less than that of Defendant.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6D.proposition: Plaintiff’s recovery of medical expenses and property loss is authorized by G.L. c. 231, § 6D, and his damages for suffering and losses are recoverable under common-law negligence principles.

(a) Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).raw_text: (a) Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (duty arising from foreseeable risk);
(a) Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: (a) Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (duty arising from foreseeable risk);
(a) Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely frames duty in negligence in terms of foreseeability of harm and expressly holds that a homeowner’s duty arose from the foreseeable risk that a mentally unstable, violent person with unsupervised access would obtain and misuse stored firearms. The court repeatedly links the existence and scope of the duty to what risks were or should have been reasonably anticipated, and ultimately imposes a duty of reasonable care on that foreseeability basis. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that duty can arise from a foreseeable risk.
(a) Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.… Consequently… ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … [W]e conclude that … [Kask] has a duty of reasonable care… because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

(b) Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454.raw_text: (b) Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009) (breach and causation);
(b) Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454.proposition: (b) Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37 (2009) (breach and causation);
(b) Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454.support_reasoning: The proposition label "(breach and causation)" matches what this opinion is actually used for: articulating and applying the elements of negligence, specifically breach and causation. The court explains that Leavitt must prove duty, breach, damages, and causal relation, and then holds both that no duty exists and, independently, that his injuries were not within the scope of foreseeable risk (i.e., no legal/proximate causation). Thus the case is appropriate authority on negligence elements, including breach and causation analysis.
(b) Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on his negligence claims, Leavitt must prove that the hospital owed him a duty of reasonable care, that the hospital committed a breach of that duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of duty and the damage. ... The hospital also claims that it should not be held liable on a separate, independent ground: the injury to Leavitt was not 'caused' by any action on its part. We agree. Leavitt’s injury was not 'caused' by the hospital because it falls outside the scope of foreseeable risk arising from any negligent conduct that would make the hospital’s alleged misconduct tortious."

(c) Zieminski v. Kenney, 19 Mass. App. C.raw_text: (c) Zieminski v. Kenney, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (1985) (proximate cause);
(c) Zieminski v. Kenney, 19 Mass. App. C.proposition: (c) Zieminski v. Kenney, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 228 (1985) (proximate cause);
(c) Zieminski v. Kenney, 19 Mass. App. C.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns personal jurisdiction over a nonresident spouse in a support-modification proceeding, and secondarily the standard for modifying alimony/child support based on a material change in circumstances. It does not analyze or apply any doctrine of proximate cause, nor does it involve tort, causation, or related concepts. Therefore it cannot properly be cited as authority on proximate cause.
(c) Zieminski v. Kenney, 19 Mass. App. C.relevant_excerpt: "In order for a petitioner to be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, he or she must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). 'The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.' Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26 (1981)."

(d) Cottrell v. N.H. Ins. Co., 82 Mass..raw_text: (d) Cottrell v. N.H. Ins. Co., 82 Mass. App. Ct. 164 (2012) (foreseeability and standard of care);
(d) Cottrell v. N.H. Ins. Co., 82 Mass..proposition: (d) Cottrell v. N.H. Ins. Co., 82 Mass. App. Ct. 164 (2012) (foreseeability and standard of care);
(d) Cottrell v. N.H. Ins. Co., 82 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided proposition text simply repeats the case citation and parenthetical and does not articulate any substantive legal rule about foreseeability or standard of care. The opinion itself concerns Fourth Amendment/Massachusetts constitutional law on traffic stops, exit orders, and searches based on the odor of marijuana, not negligence, foreseeability, or standard of care. Accordingly, as framed, the proposition is not actually supported by this case.
(d) Cottrell v. N.H. Ins. Co., 82 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Ordinarily, ‘[w]hen the police are justified in stopping an automobile for a routine traffic violation, they may, for their safety and the safety of the public, order the driver or the passengers to leave the automobile, but only if they have a reasonable belief that their safety, or the safety of others, is in danger.’ Commonwealth v. Torres, 433 Mass. 669, 673 (2001). ‘To determine whether such a belief is reasonable, [the reviewing court asks] ‘whether a reasonably prudent man in the policeman’s position would be warranted’ in such a belief.’”

(i) Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 M.raw_text: (i) Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983) (foreseeability and duty);
(i) Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 M.proposition: (i) Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983) (foreseeability and duty);
(i) Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 M.support_reasoning: The supplied text is a dissent focused on lack of proximate cause and on limits of foreseeability in this particular factual context, not on recognizing or elaborating a general duty based on foreseeability. The majority in Mullins is well-known for addressing foreseeability and duty in the context of college security, but that discussion does not appear in this excerpt. Since the question must be answered based only on the provided opinion text, this passage does not itself support the proposition that Mullins establishes a foreseeability-based duty rule; it actually narrows foreseeability for proximate cause instead.
(i) Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 M.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving 'that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.' Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969)."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award costs pursuant to Mass. R. Civ. P. 54(d) and statutory interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
